restaurants.bio: This Bengali spot is just a few blocks from Villa Brazil on the border of Astoria and Dutch Kills. They do tea, snacks, and of course sweets, but Khan recommends diving deep into the menu. Our food is extremely different from the Indian cuisine you find in most restaurants. We focus more on stews, stir fries, and fish. Mustard oil is our best friend and we use it on everything. Check out Aladdin—one of the oldest and best Bangladeshi restaurants in the city. Get the chicken roll as an appetizer, the curry beef, ANY of the fresh fish available that day, and don’t forget the tehari! I actually think it’s better than biryani.
restaurants.name: Aladdin Sweets and Restaurant

restaurants.bio: It’s hard not to be in a good mood at this neon-lit, 24-hour Colombian diner.
restaurants.name: Cositas Ricas

restaurants.bio: A Colombian coffee shop with great empanadas.
restaurants.name: Salento

restaurants.bio: At Arepa Lady in Jackson Heights, you eat arepas. Get at least one with queso.
restaurants.name: Arepa Lady

restaurants.bio: If your definition of a sandwich is “large amount of meat on bread,” head up to Pastrami Queen, located just a block from the 77th Street 6 stop. This kosher deli makes pastrami sandwiches that rival Katz’s. The corned beef and roast turkey are great too, as is the matzo ball soup, but that’s a weird thing to eat in the park.
restaurants.name: Pastrami Queen

restaurants.bio: You grabbed your blanket from your couch and filled your cooler. Now you just need to pick up some food and you’ll finally be one of those people who comes to Central Park prepared. Stop by Zabar’s - a gourmet deli and grocer on the Upper West Side - and get some seriously good pastrami sandwiches, or go for a baguette with a few different cheeses and cured meats.
restaurants.name: Zabar's

restaurants.bio: Our only complaints with this Upper East Side spot are the spotty service and the high prices of their non-sandwich menu items. Bypass both of these issues by grabbing some really good paninis to-go, and taking them to the park a block away. The sandwiches here, like the one with prosciutto and shrimp, are excellent and come wrapped tightly in tin foil, so they’ll stay warm and toasty until you find your perfect plot of grass.
restaurants.name: Via Quadronno

restaurants.bio: Your plan was to find an open park bench and get through an entire Sunday Times, but you’re already running behind and that piece on two startup founders trying to find a $2000 two-bedroom in Soho isn’t going to read itself. One of your best quick options is Breads - a bakery and cafe less than a block off the park on the Upper West Side. Grab coffee and a breakfast sandwich, and definitely try the chocolate babka.
restaurants.name: Breads Bakery

restaurants.bio: While it would probably be worth waiting in line at Russ & Daughters’ shop on Houston and transporting everything uptown for a bagel and lox feast, you could save a couple hours by popping into their lesser-known location in the basement of the Jewish Museum just off the park on the UES. Just know you can’t do takeout or walk in for a meal on Saturdays (when it’s prepaid- and reservation-only due to Shabbat), and they’re closed on Wednesdays.
restaurants.name: Russ & Daughters At The Jewish Museum

restaurants.bio: All you’ve had to eat since getting to the park is a street cart hot dog and a bag of Ruffles. If you want some high-quality food close by in a place that still feels casual, get one of the outdoor tables at The East Pole. This Upper East Side spot serves a bunch of healthy options all day, along with a very good bacon cheeseburger with duck fat steak fries.
restaurants.name: The East Pole

restaurants.bio: After a long day of sun, rowboats, and avoiding horsesh*t, you may want to turn things up a notch with spicy margaritas and buckets of beer. Playa Betty’s is a fun spot on the Upper West Side where you can roll in wearing grass-stained shorts, and eat tacos and guacamole with a big group.
restaurants.name: Playa Betty's

restaurants.bio: Blue Ribbon Brasserie is a little restaurant on Sullivan Street with white tablecloths and a menu that has everything from steak and lobster to chicken wings and matzoh ball soup. It’s open until 2am every day, and if we could only put one place on this list, this would be it. Blue Ribbon is the rare restaurant that gets even better after midnight.
restaurants.name: Blue Ribbon Brasserie

restaurants.bio: You can eat some of the best Thai food in NYC after midnight. Isan Thai specialist Zaab Zaab is open until 1am daily, and they have two locations. The Williamsburg space is bigger and more convenient for anyone who’s spending a night out on one of the many dance floors in the area.
restaurants.name: Zaab Zaab

restaurants.bio: Laser Wolf is hard to get into, but if you’re willing to eat at 11:30pm, you can achieve your dream of eating grilled meats on the roof of a Williamsburg hotel. This Israeli skewer house is open until 1am Thursday through Saturday.
restaurants.name: Laser Wolf

restaurants.bio: Double Chicken Please is half restaurant, half bar, so it makes sense that this place is open late. They serve a small menu of fried chicken sandwiches until midnight on weekends.
restaurants.name: Double Chicken Please

restaurants.bio: With their late-night menu and festive, neon-lit dining room, this Park Slope restaurant is the ideal place to hang out and enjoy a bunch of food after midnight.
restaurants.name: Medusa The Greek

restaurants.bio: Hidden behind a secret door in a Soho taqueria, this subterranean restaurant feels like a dark dungeon where people go to drink margaritas. It’s been around for over a decade now, and it’s still pretty fun.
restaurants.name: La Esquina Brasserie

restaurants.bio: This bistro near Union Square operates until 4am on Fridays and Saturdays, and it serves classic French dishes like escargots and some of the best french onion soup in the city.
restaurants.name: L'Express
restaurants.address: 249 Park Ave. S New York, NY 10003

restaurants.bio: Jongro is one of our favorite Korean barbecue spots, and it’s pretty much always busy. They’re open until 1am on weekends.
restaurants.name: Jongro BBQ
restaurants.address: 22 W 32nd St Fl 2 New York, NY 10001

restaurants.bio: After an encore performance of karaoke, get a late meal at Pocha 32 (open until at least 2am every night). You won’t be the only ones here.
restaurants.name: Pocha 32

restaurants.bio: If you’re out at a bar in the East Village and you suddenly feel inspired to sit down and eat pasta, go to Lil Frankie’s. It’s a big cash-only Italian restaurant open until 2am daily.
restaurants.name: Lil Frankies

restaurants.bio: Uva is a neighborhood Italian restaurant that’s perfect for date night on the Upper East Side, and it’s open until 1am every day except Monday.
restaurants.name: Uva

restaurants.bio: A romantic getaway to some alpine destination where you can say “chalet” unironically probably isn’t in the cards right now. But The Greens is a pretty strong substitute. Reserve a private cabin on the rooftop of Pier 17 at the Seaport during lunch or dinner, and share fondue and hot toddies while checking out your own virtual fireplace or the floor-to-ceiling views of the Brooklyn Bridge.
restaurants.name: The Greens

restaurants.bio: Peaches Hot House is one of the many Peaches offshoots that specializes in Nashville hot chicken. Come here when you need a reminder about why hot sauce matters, are craving a side of mac and cheese to your order, or just want to have a meal in one of their private greenhouses along their sidewalk.
restaurants.name: Peaches Hothouse

restaurants.bio: There are only a few great dinner spots that could both fit on this guide and work for a night out with a few friends, a casual date, or dinner with your roommate. Haenyeo is one of them. The menu ranges from scallion pancakes and bibimbap to KBBQ that comes out on sizzling platters, and they’ve got heated, enclosed pods on their outdoor patio where Cyndi Lauper apparently likes to have lunch.
restaurants.name: Haenyeo

restaurants.bio: The food alone at Crown Shy makes it one of the best restaurants in NYC. But now that this American spot in Fidi has festively-decorated private yurts running along Pine Street, it’s also one of the best outdoor dining experiences you can have anywhere in the city this winter.
restaurants.name: Crown Shy

restaurants.bio: We’d like to think tailgating has prepared us for our current situation of huddling in the cold watching sports, but we’ll still take some heat lamps. Which is exactly what’s being offered at this new outdoor sports bar in Williamsburg. Along with heated cabanas, they’re always serving up specials, like their “Puppybowl brunch” they hosted on the day of the Super Bowl.
restaurants.name: TailGate Outdoor Sports Bar

restaurants.bio: The Lower East Side location of this casual Italian restaurant has a couple of bubble tables on Grand Street available for lunch and dinner. They’re just big enough for two people, which means you’ll only have to share your pizza, garlic knot sliders, and chicken wings with one other person.
restaurants.name: Saluggi's East

restaurants.bio: After renovating the entire restaurant himself, the head chef and owner of Leland Eating & Drinking House opened this Prospect Heights spot on a quiet corner just off of Washington Avenue. On the sidewalk patio, you’ll see a few private, heated outdoor shacks they’re calling “cozy cabins,” but there’s also a takeout window where you can pick up a pastry, bottle of wine, or cocktail to go.
restaurants.name: Leland Eating & Drinking House

restaurants.bio: Mika is a beer bar with a space in Bushwick that could easily handle a wedding in the before times. It’s massive. Their outdoor area has a few spaced-out tables, as well as two plastic tents where you can use wifi to get work done or have drinks. You’ll have to go through Mika’s indoor area to get to the backyard, and they will check your temperature and ask for contact info for tracing purposes.
restaurants.name: Mika

restaurants.bio: This French bistro on the UWS installed clear plastic domes to cover each of their outdoor tables. So, instead of wind gusts and rain, moule frites, wine, live jazz, and friends or a date will have your full attention. These domes can be reserved through the restaurant’s website.
restaurants.name: Cafe Du Soleil

restaurants.bio: Honey Badger in Prospect Lefferts Gardens has fully committed to creating new outdoor architecture: they built a chic, wooden lean-to house where you can stay dry and warm while you eat. The experimental tasting menu here changes often, but it’s always focused on whatever is in season.
restaurants.name: Honey Badger

restaurants.bio: Industry Kitchen has installed a few personal table coverings to block undesirable weather. Unlike Cafe Du Soleil’s bubble domes, this pizza and salad spot on the East River has table tents that look more like tiny clear houses.
restaurants.name: Industry Kitchen

restaurants.bio: Hane Sushi in Stuytown has both enclosed bubbles over individual tables as well as an area with a large outdoor tent with flaps on all sides. You can stop by for a spicy yellowtail roll or $21 sushi combo platter for lunch or dinner every day.
restaurants.name: Hane Sushi

restaurants.bio: If you’re looking for another option right on the water (without water being the thing that actually ruins your meal) consider Estuary in Brooklyn Bridge Park. They have private table coverings which we’re formally going to start calling “table houses.”
restaurants.name: Estuary

restaurants.bio: This rooftop restaurant in FiDi opened back in July, and each of their outdoor tables has its own clear hut. You have to call to reserve one of their enclosed outdoor tables at least seven days in advance.
restaurants.name: Ampia
restaurants.address: 100 Broad St Fl 2 New York, NY 10004

restaurants.bio: Another UWS restaurant with table houses is Lucciola. This Italian restaurant has an eight-person maximum for their fully-covered tables.
restaurants.name: Lucciola

restaurants.bio: Ridgewood has many solid slice shops and sit-down pizza joints. Eat at all of them, but start at Mano’s. The counter-service spot on the north end of Forest Ave. has only been open since 2021, but it’s already established itself as one of NYC’s best. Fermented for days, the crust on their pies is thin and crackly, with big pockets of air.
restaurants.name: Mano's Pizzeria

restaurants.bio: Mama Yoshi Mini Mart, a Japanese-inspired konbini, is a newer entry in the field, and it makes an incredible fried chicken katsu sandwich. Get the spicy version, which comes with an enormous cutlet that crunches and burns as it goes down.
restaurants.name: Mama Yoshi Mini Mart

restaurants.bio: For a hearty meal that’ll run you less than $20 per person, choose Rico Pollo every time. The casual Dominican restaurant serves some of the crispiest pernil in the city, as well as thick chicharron that has an impeccable crunch.
restaurants.name: Rico Pollo

restaurants.bio: This wood-fired restaurant founded by a few Gramercy Tavern alums seems casual, but Rolo’s is actually a very serious restaurant that pumps out seriously tasty, detail-oriented food.
restaurants.name: Rolo's

restaurants.bio: Momos in paratha shouldn’t work. The concept sounds too carb-heavy, but Mount Everest Deli & Grocery pulls it off exquisitely.
restaurants.name: Everest Grocery & Deli

restaurants.bio: Pupusas Ridgewood can fit, at most, two people (standing) at one time. The closet-sized counter-service spot serves over 10 different kinds of pupusas.
restaurants.name: Pupusas Ridgewood
restaurants.address: 7120 Fresh Pond Rd New York, NY 11385

restaurants.bio: Venezuelan street food specialist Cachapas y Mas does patacones, arepas, yoyos, pepitos, and cachapas as well.
restaurants.name: Cachapas y Mas

restaurants.bio: This old-school Italian spot has been perfecting its chicken marsala recipe since 1982.
restaurants.name: Joe's Restaurant
restaurants.address: 6611 Forest Ave New York, New York

restaurants.bio: Should you need a perfect, crunchy Sicilian slice—or maybe a round pie topped with chicken parm—Joe & John’s is the answer.
restaurants.name: Joe & John's Pizzeria

restaurants.bio: If you’re in the market for a can of kajmak or a pound of kielbasa, Hetman Polish Deli can help with that.
restaurants.name: Hetman Polish Deli and Foods

restaurants.bio: There are many reasons to spend time at Aunt Ginny’s, but if we had to pick one, it would be I Like Food.
restaurants.name: I Like Food

restaurants.bio: While In Kathmandu is a neighborhood clubhouse catering to those who’d rather not spend over $30 on dinner.
restaurants.name: While in Kathmandu

restaurants.bio: Decades is a pizza parlor for people who remember dining at Pizza Hut back in the day.
restaurants.name: Decades

restaurants.bio: Rudy’s makes a mean bienenstich. The place was, after all, founded as a German bakery in the 1930s.
restaurants.name: Rudy's Bakery and Cafe

restaurants.bio: The breakfast burrito at Mama Yoshi is a very decent choice, but Norma’s is the first spot you should think of.
restaurants.name: Norma's

restaurants.bio: If it’s specifically quesadillas you’re after—and it should be—head to Las Chilangas.
restaurants.name: Las Chilangas

restaurants.bio: Before there was Rolo’s, there was Ltauha. The original Ridgewood American bistro.
restaurants.name: Ltauha

restaurants.bio: Ecuadorian food is a big part of Ridgewood. There are a lot of good street vendors and sit-down spots.
restaurants.name: M&S Bakery
restaurants.address: 819 Seneca Ave New York, New York 11385

restaurants.bio: The glasses of wine at Antica Trattoria start around $9, and the pastas are all under $20.
restaurants.name: Antica Trattoria

restaurants.bio: Hellbender gets some flack for being one of the more expensive options in the area.
restaurants.name: Hellbender
restaurants.address: 68-22 Forest Ave New York, New York 11385

restaurants.bio: Harry’s Italian in Battery Park is serving its red-sauce Italian dishes, pizzas, and calzones for pickup and delivery. It’s also offering family-style dinners that include your choice of salad or appetizer, pasta, and entree for $59.95 per person.
restaurants.name: Harry's Italian Pizza Bar

restaurants.bio: You could eat the leftover baby spinach salad for lunch. Or you could order sushi rolls and pork katsu from Sushi Damo on UberEats every day starting at noon.
restaurants.name: Sushi Damo

restaurants.bio: The makers of one of our favorite burgers in New York City have set up shop in Sag Harbor. Like Red Hook Tavern, they’ll have American classics like steaks and a thick, hockey puck-like burger at the new spot Out East. And because it’s the Hamptons, they’ll likely have a higher density of seafood dishes than they have back in Brooklyn.
restaurants.name: Sag Harbor Tavern
restaurants.address: 26 Bay St, Sag Harbor, New York 11963

restaurants.bio: This new seafood spot is located right on the water, and it’s one of the only places in the area where you can dock your boat (or your rich friend’s boat) and dine on the umbrella-covered patio. In typical Montauk fashion, the menu is full of crudos and other oceanic treats, like dungeness crab ravioli.
restaurants.name: N'amo
restaurants.address: 474 W Lake Dr, Montauk, New York 11954

restaurants.bio: I've gone through all the phases. When Chop't opened, I was obsessed. Who knew you could eat such a volume of salad? They're huge, and they're amazing. And, of course, I did Sweetgreen too. Right now I'm really loving Just Salad. I don't order one that's on the menu. I make my own. It probably has a thousand calories, and it has everything in it from pumpkin seeds to almonds, tortilla chips, chickpeas, quinoa, carrots—like, all the things. And then sometimes, if I order it to the office, I'll make my own dressing because I'm so particular. But other times I just get their balsamic vinaigrette and their creamy Caesar and I do three parts balsamic vinaigrette and a little creamy Caesar and it's so good.
restaurants.name: Just Salad

restaurants.bio: Every Saturday and Sunday between noon and 5pm, this South Bronx spot hosts bottomless brunch with live DJs or drummers (like this incredible drummer named Anthony Anderson) as well as unlimited mimosas and sangria for $24.
restaurants.name: Beatstro

restaurants.bio: Almost everything at this Greenpoint taqueria is modeled after Mexico City’s legendary eateries, complete with colorful plastic plates and a comal custom-made in CDMX. Their tacos range from shredded suadero and al pastor, to longaniza with bright orange porky juices.
restaurants.name: Taqueria Ramirez

restaurants.bio: Across from Corona Plaza, in the shadow of the 7 train tracks, there’s a street cart selling tlayudas wider than a steering wheel. We’re talking a crisp layer of freshly griddled masa, topped with cheese, beans, shredded lettuce, and your choice of meat.
restaurants.name: Tlayuda Oaxaqueña Sr San Pablo
restaurants.address: 102-25 Roosevelt Ave New York, New York 11368

restaurants.bio: Everything at Ensenada is good, and we don’t make that statement lightly. This beachy seafood spot in Williamsburg makes buttery tuna tostadas, saucy shrimp tacos, and three types of aguachile.
restaurants.name: Ensenada

restaurants.bio: This Tijuana-style spot is a New York City landmark, like the Statue of Liberty, except it’s a truck under the subway track in Jackson Heights. Birria-Landia now has four other locations from the Bronx to the Lower East Side.
restaurants.name: Birria-Landia

restaurants.bio: Carnitas Ramirez—the carnitas-only East Village sequel to Taqueria Ramirez—is an education in just how many different, pleasurable textures can be derived from one animal.
restaurants.name: Carnitas Ramirez
restaurants.address: 210 E 3rd St New York, New York 10009

restaurants.bio: For a food truck that sees the most action after midnight, El Jalapeño doesn’t need to be as good as it is. You can’t go wrong with any order, but the spicy pork burrito is our favorite.
restaurants.name: El Jalapeño
restaurants.address: 204 W Fourth St New York, New York 10014

restaurants.bio: Chalupas Poblanas El Tlecuile is a cash-only chalupa stand in Jackson Heights that operates outside of a Chipotle, of all places.
restaurants.name: Chalupas Poblanas El Tlecuile

restaurants.bio: We love all the seafood at this restaurant in Jackson Heights, but a meal here is incomplete without an order of Submarino ceviche.
restaurants.name: Mariscos El Submarino

restaurants.bio: Filled with jet black accents and dim spotlights above each table, this upscale Flatiron restaurant works best for special occasions.
restaurants.name: Cosme

restaurants.bio: Painted an unmissable, electric Frida Kahlo-blue, this little restaurant in Hamilton Heights grew out of a pandemic supper club run by couple Karina Garcia and Lalo Rodriguez.
restaurants.name: Cocina Consuelo
restaurants.address: 130 Hamilton Pl New York, New York 10031

restaurants.bio: A tidy scoop of refried beans topped with queso fresco. A jiggly sunny-side-up egg submerged in chunky salsa roja.
restaurants.name: Ánimo

restaurants.bio: You should, of course, order the al pastor tacos at Taqueria Al Pastor, a counter-service spot in Bushwick.
restaurants.name: Taqueria Al Pastor

restaurants.bio: For All Things Good runs on masa, but you won’t find any tacos at this minimalist Bed-Stuy spot that looks like a coffee shop.
restaurants.name: For All Things Good

restaurants.bio: La Morada in Mott Haven is in one lavender room with the lighting scheme of a dental office.
restaurants.name: La Morada

restaurants.bio: El Kallejon in East Harlem looks like the mercado of your dreams—Huichol cats, rainbow piñatas.
restaurants.name: El Kallejon

restaurants.bio: This Tijuana-style taco shop started in Chelsea Market in 2013, and you’ll still consistently find lines there any time you go.
restaurants.name: Los Tacos No. 1

restaurants.bio: This Long Island City restaurant made waves when it first opened in 2012, and everything from the ceviche to the chile relleno served in a little pool of mildly sweet sauce is still excellent there.
restaurants.name: Casa Enrique

restaurants.bio: If you’ve been searching for a Mexican restaurant in Park Slope that you can get excited about, you can stop.
restaurants.name: Casa Azul

restaurants.bio: Some things at Oxomoco in Greenpoint are optional. Starting out with a margarita or giant frozen cocktail is not.
restaurants.name: Oxomoco

restaurants.bio: Tacos El Bronco operates two trucks and a brick-and-mortar location in Sunset Park with a long dining room with a mural of broncos.
restaurants.name: Tacos El Bronco

restaurants.bio: From the daily brunch to mezcal flights, Ruta Oaxaca takes the maximalist approach at every turn.
restaurants.name: Ruta Oaxaca

restaurants.bio: On any given night, you may find us closing our eyes and pretending we’re sitting at Claro’s outdoor bar underneath some twinkly lights.
restaurants.name: Claro

restaurants.bio: Conceived as a steakhouse but for fish, this Nomad restaurant from the Crown Shy/Saga team serves inventive, special-occasion seafood that won't leave you missing red meat. The halibut pithivier, a stunning undersea wellington in burnished puff pastry, is destined for your Instagram grid.
restaurants.name: Time And Tide
restaurants.address: 48 E 26th St New York, New York 10010

restaurants.bio: If you're looking for the city's best lobster roll, this East Village spot from a Claud alum wins. Saucy, rich, and filled with cubes of lobster so tender they're almost raw.
restaurants.name: Smithereens
restaurants.address: 414 E 9th St New York, New York 10009

restaurants.bio: Sitting in Crevette’s big dining room, slurping down oysters with coriander mignonette and mussels with a smoky brava sauce, you could easily be convinced that you’re somewhere in the south of France.
restaurants.name: Crevette
restaurants.address: 10 Downing St New York, New York 10014

restaurants.bio: The Williamsburg Mexican seafood oasis works for just about any occasion—a third date, a solo Happy Hour at the bar, your dad’s birthday.
restaurants.name: Ensenada

restaurants.bio: At Penny in the East Village, the Argentinian shrimp are a finger long, a little sweet, cost $4.50 each—and we ordered three more immediately after the first round.
restaurants.name: Penny
restaurants.address: 90 E 10th St New York, New York 10003

restaurants.bio: Dry-aged branzino tastes better when roasted in a charcoal oven and served in a beige room best described as desert chic.
restaurants.name: Theodora
restaurants.address: 7 Greene Ave New York, New York 11238

restaurants.bio: For your next anniversary, book a table at Le Bernardin. The Midtown fine-dining staple serves a bit of filet mignon here and there, but otherwise it’s pretty much all seafood.
restaurants.name: Le Bernardin
restaurants.address: W 51st Street New York City, New York 10019

restaurants.bio: Quique Crudo only seats around 20 at a bar and a few small counters. This is the rare West Village establishment that hasn't been hyped to death.
restaurants.name: Quique Crudo
restaurants.address: 27 Bedford St New York, New York 10014

restaurants.bio: This stall in Flushing’s bustling New York Food Court puts crab roe—a Shanghainese specialty—front and center in many of its incredible dishes.
restaurants.name: Xie Bao
restaurants.address: 133-35 Roosevelt Ave, Flushing, NY New York, NY 11354

restaurants.bio: This New Orleans-inspired spot in Fort Greene serves oysters five ways and offers shrimp in states ranging from cocktail to remoulade.
restaurants.name: Strange Delight
restaurants.address: 63 Lafayette Ave New York, New York 11217

restaurants.bio: British seafood isn’t just fish and chips. At Dame in Greenwich Village, it also means smoked whitefish croquettes and tuna tartare on toast.
restaurants.name: Dame

restaurants.bio: This counter-service spot tucked into the side of Chelsea Market serves fantastic fish tacos, ceviche, and aguachile.
restaurants.name: Los Mariscos

restaurants.bio: At Chuan Tian Xia, the fish breathe fire. You’ll see a lot of whole fish here, like groupers and tilapias, skin on with their mouths agape.
restaurants.name: Chuan Tian Xia

restaurants.bio: Cervo’s is where you can eat Spanish and Portuguese seafood while you take in a candlelit scene.
restaurants.name: Cervo's

restaurants.bio: Ganjang gejang, raw soy-marinated crab, is a classic Korean dish that’s rarely a primary focus for restaurants.
restaurants.name: Rice Thief

restaurants.bio: Astoria Seafood combines a BYOB experience with the thrills of grocery shopping.
restaurants.name: Astoria Seafood

restaurants.bio: Get in a car (or hop on a bus) and make your way to this City Island institution, where you can dive into a pile of fried shrimp.
restaurants.name: Johnny's Reef

restaurants.bio: Plan a group meal at Wu’s Wonton King on the border of Chinatown and the Lower East Side.
restaurants.name: Wu's Wonton King

restaurants.bio: Abuqir is similar to Astoria Seafood, with a few key differences: it’s Egyptian, and there isn't much seating.
restaurants.name: Abuqir

restaurants.bio: Across the street from Central Park, Marea specializes in housemade pastas accessorized with lobster, shrimp, and other ingredients that were recently dragged from the sea.
restaurants.name: Marea
restaurants.address: 240 Central Park S. New York, NY 10019

restaurants.bio: It’s been too long since you visited Grand Central Oyster Bar. We get it—subjecting yourself to a Grand Central Terminal visit without a train to catch feels wrong.
restaurants.name: Grand Central Oyster Bar

restaurants.bio: There are a lot of places to eat raw seafood in NYC, but not many of them are so close to the water that you could eat a raw clam and then throw your shell into the sea.
restaurants.name: Randazzo's Clam Bar

restaurants.bio: There are several ways to approach a meal at Bunna, a lowkey Bushwick cafe that’s consistently packed. The easiest route is The Feast: a giant plate of everything main on the menu, like miser wot, gomen, shiro, and kale salad with avocado. Everyone gets their own personal pile of injera so no need to fight anyone for the last piece.
restaurants.name: Bunna Cafe

restaurants.bio: This vegan Ethiopian restaurant—with a second location in Greenwich Village—has a Biggie Smalls-heavy soundtrack, impressively colorful murals, and crowd-pleasing platters of spongy injera, topped with things like creamy ground chickpeas, and crispy green beans. It’s great for a group dinner that will satisfy both vegans and people who have never tried a chickpea before, or a casual catch-up with a friend.
restaurants.name: Ras Plant Based

restaurants.bio: An offshoot of Ethiopian/Eritrean institution Massawa, this Morningside Heights restaurant is a good place to get coffee and work, then get a glass of South African wine and pretend to work, and then share a tibs quesadilla with a friend and give up on work altogether. You can get extra-soft injera covered with a solid, steaming assortment of meat and lentil dishes, but dipping into the snacky portion of the menu for things like berbere wings is a good idea too.
restaurants.name: Cafe Massawa

restaurants.bio: On Avenue B, Haile is the kind of place that instantly makes you feel like you’re at your best friend’s house. There’s a lot of seating, and even though there’s almost always a small crowd of regulars, it never gets annoyingly busy. This is a restaurant you’ll return to often, not just for the exceptional shiro wot, which coats everything it meets with garlicky creaminess, but to say hi to your favorite host again.
restaurants.name: Haile

restaurants.bio: With white tablecloths and perfect sambusas, this Upper West Side classic is a great option for a special occasion group dinner when you don’t want to spend hundreds of dollars on an outstanding meal, but still want to have a memorable night. But Awash works equally well for a lowkey date night or a solo meal with an order of their excellent kitfo.
restaurants.name: Awash Ethiopian Restaurant

restaurants.bio: Near Jackie Robinson Park in Harlem, Benyam is a charming, art-filled family-run spot with a couple of outdoor seats, affordable bottles of wine, and mitmita that comes to your table along with a wink and a warning to watch out for the spice mix. The injera here is especially tangy (you can get it gluten-free if you call them in advance), and the mixed platter with kitfo is a great choice.
restaurants.name: Benyam
restaurants.address: 2795 Frederick Douglass Blvd New York, NY 10039

restaurants.bio: Abyssinia in Harlem is an ideal spot to bring a friend or go on a date once you get to the phase in your relationship where you don’t mind sharing some excellent spicy beef stew off of the same plate. The food here is extremely good, and all of the vegetable dishes are fully vegan. Get the meat or vegetable combo, and between the different stews, injera bread and vegetable sides, you’ll have a ton of food for around $30 per person.
restaurants.name: Abyssinia
restaurants.address: 268 W 135th St. New York, New York 10030

restaurants.bio: This casual spot on the border of Park Slope and Gowanus is a reliable choice for group dinners, especially if there are vegans in the mix. Big windows let light in under a faux-thatched ceiling, and booths make it easy to get cozy around a bunch of delicious food. We always go for the combinations here—the vegan option is $99 for four people and comes with four stews—because it’s such a good deal.
restaurants.name: Ghenet

restaurants.bio: Whether your friend group is fully vegetarian, or it’s the one vegan’s turn to choose, Bersi is a plant-based Ethiopian restaurant that everyone will enjoy. Stewed vegetables and spiced lentils make this cuisine one of our go-to’s for a vegetarian meal—but the best dishes at Bersi are actually the ones traditionally made with meat, like mushroom tibs and red lentil kitfo. Everything comes on one big round of injera, and the best part of the meal is sharing the spongy, spice-soaked bread at the end.
restaurants.name: Bersi

restaurants.bio: Dame got its start as a beloved pandemic-era fish and chips pop-up, and at their brick-and-mortar on MacDougal Street, you can get those, plus a bunch of other precious-feeling seafood plates.
restaurants.name: Dame

restaurants.bio: If you're looking for a spendy special occasion spot in Greenwich Village, there's no better option than Minetta Tavern.
restaurants.name: Minetta Tavern

restaurants.bio: The closest thing us New Yorkers have to The Devonshire in London, Lord’s is a very fancy pub that comes from the team behind Dame.
restaurants.name: Lord's

restaurants.bio: Da Toscano stands out among the many Italian restaurants in lower Manhattan.
restaurants.name: Da Toscano

restaurants.bio: Acru’s $95 tasting menu incorporates Australian, Scandinavian, and Korean cooking styles into dishes.
restaurants.name: Acru
restaurants.address: 79 MacDougal St New York, New York 10012

restaurants.bio: Loring Place is one of those restaurants that will make you feel really excited about broccoli.
restaurants.name: Loring Place

restaurants.bio: Shmoné is the only restaurant where we’ve ordered another bottle of wine after finishing dessert.
restaurants.name: Shmoné

restaurants.bio: Bar Moga is a Japanese spot where you can pair your impeccably-made cocktail with a pork katsu sando.
restaurants.name: Bar Moga
restaurants.address: 128 W Houston St New York, NY 10012

restaurants.bio: Carbone’s reputation precedes itself. It's one of the most divisive restaurants in NYC.
restaurants.name: Carbone

restaurants.bio: The Dao Kou chicken at this tiny Chinese spot on Bleeker simmers in a hot five-spice broth jacuzzi for several hours.
restaurants.name: Cauldron Chicken
restaurants.address: 190 Bleecker St New York, New York 10012

restaurants.bio: Ras Plant Based is a vegan Ethiopian restaurant, but it’s got the sort of crowd-pleasing menu that will satisfy even the friend who is single-handedly keeping the red meat industry afloat.
restaurants.name: Ras Plant Based
restaurants.address: 170 Bleecker St New York, New York 10012

restaurants.bio: Dante is a restaurant where the main reason to come is to sit outside and drink.
restaurants.name: Dante

restaurants.bio: Kazumi is notable for a meal that tastes more expensive than it is.
restaurants.name: Kazumi Omakase
restaurants.address: 31 W Eighth St New York, New York 10011

restaurants.bio: Old Tbilisi Garden is elbow-deep in their gooey cheese-laden ajaruli khachapuri.
restaurants.name: Old Tbilisi Garden

restaurants.bio: Thelewala is a kathi roll and chaat counter where you can grab something portable to eat.
restaurants.name: Thelewala

restaurants.bio: Il Cantinori is where to drink an espresso martini in Greenwich Village.
restaurants.name: Il Cantinori

restaurants.bio: Tomo21 has a steady stream of takeout orders, but it’s worth waiting to dine in.
restaurants.name: Tomo21 Sushi

restaurants.bio: Gene’s opened in 1919, and it’s not just Sarah Jessica Parker’s favorite restaurant.
restaurants.name: Gene's Restaurant

restaurants.bio: Bar Pitti is a constant scene, and it's not necessarily due to the food being great.
restaurants.name: Bar Pitti

restaurants.bio: Butter Smashburgers doesn’t reinvent the wheel, but they are a one-stop-shop for crispy smashburgers.
restaurants.name: Butter Smashburgers
restaurants.address: 106 MacDougal St New York, New York 10012

restaurants.bio: Villa Mosconi dances to its own tune, several steps out of time with the rest of the neighborhood.
restaurants.name: Villa Mosconi

restaurants.bio: From the team behind Rezdôra, Massara is a two-story restaurant that uses everything at its disposal to place you in Southern Italy. It’s a fun party trick, and it works. The floors are travertine flagstone, the olive-green walls are hung with vintage paintings, and the intricate food is inspired by Campania.
restaurants.name: Massara

restaurants.bio: Gramercy Tavern’s upscale dining room in the back is where you can eat their tasting menu for $175. If you want a special-occasion spot that feels like someone’s very nice home in Aspen, that’s where you should sit.
restaurants.name: Gramercy Tavern

restaurants.bio: The Mexican food scene in NYC has changed enormously since Cosme opened in 2014, but this place still feels fresh and new. Budget around $100 per person, and come by for some chunky herb guacamole and the uni tostada with bone marrow salsa.
restaurants.name: Cosme

restaurants.bio: Cote, a cross between a steakhouse and a Korean barbecue joint, remains impossible to get into, and there’s a reason for that. The quality of the beef is fantastic, and the $78 prix fixe is a great deal for what you get.
restaurants.name: Cote

restaurants.bio: At London import Hawksmoor, you can enjoy all of those things in a green leather booth beneath arched ceilings. The filet is our cut of choice at this British steakhouse, but you should also try the charcoal-roasted lobster.
restaurants.name: Hawksmoor NYC

restaurants.bio: From the chef behind Moono, this restaurant serves a seven-course, $140 tasting menu in a space with brick walls and scuffed concrete floors.
restaurants.name: Jua

restaurants.bio: Coqodaq offers a set meal, which costs $42 per person and comes with banchan, cold noodles, and two types of ultra crunchy, gluten-free fried chicken.
restaurants.name: Coqodaq
restaurants.address: 12 E 22nd St New York, New York 10010

restaurants.bio: Rezdôra excels at pasta, specifically those of Emilia-Romagna. The little brick-walled spot has built a strong following with its meaty modenese ragu and wallet-sized raviolo topped with black truffle.
restaurants.name: Rezdôra

restaurants.bio: This elegant Korean restaurant looks a little like a nightclub. You can order a la carte at the bar, but the $150 prix fixe is the only format available in the dining room.
restaurants.name: Oiji Mi

restaurants.bio: S&P stayed true to the old-school spirit of its predecessor, offering an expansive menu of lunchtime staples in its pretty much unchanged, narrow, diner-like space.
restaurants.name: S&P

restaurants.bio: Dinner at this lush, leafy-wallpapered Indian restaurant is like picnicking in a meadow at dusk—if that meadow happened to serve excellent cocktails.
restaurants.name: Passerine

restaurants.bio: Mari Vanna looks like something out of a Dickens novel, and has a devoted following among those who have strong feelings toward chicken kiev.
restaurants.name: Mari Vanna

restaurants.bio: Upland works for everything. Dinner, lunch, brunch—the American restaurant does it all, and has room for every single member of your book club or extended family.
restaurants.name: Upland
restaurants.address: 345 Park Avenue South New York, NY 10010

restaurants.bio: With its tiled floors, high ceilings, and tidy, cushioned booths, Stretch looks like a slightly nicer version of your average pizza parlor.
restaurants.name: Stretch Pizza
restaurants.address: 331 Park Ave S New York, NY 10010

restaurants.bio: Rebel is a Haitian spot on the Lower East Side that always makes you feel like you're at a house party.
restaurants.name: Rebel Restaurant and Bar

restaurants.bio: Stag’s Head looks like it’s going to be a bro scene, largely due to its Turtle Bay location. But it’s really more of a beer scene. Stag’s Head excels at going beyond the typical roster of Ballast Point taps, so if you’re into deep cuts of craft beer, you’ll be happy here.
restaurants.name: The Stag's Head

restaurants.bio: Think you can’t get a best-in-class meal in midtown? You are wrong, and Ippudo’s here to prove it. The ramen here is just as impressive as the Rockettes’ high kicking – we promise.
restaurants.name: Ippudo Westside

restaurants.bio: Exhibit B: the burger from Burger Joint is another best-in-category food item within walking distance of Radio City. Though this place is hidden behind a red curtain at Le Parker Meridien hotel, it’s not a secret, and the lines here can get a little out of hand – best not to come dangerously hangry.
restaurants.name: Burger Joint

restaurants.bio: If your concert tickets have left your wallet feeling light, Halal Guys is your best cheap eats option in the area. Don’t be intimidated by the line – it moves quickly and this tasty street food (particularly the lamb) is worth it.
restaurants.name: The Halal Guys

restaurants.bio: Toloache offers a vibrant atmosphere and delicious Mexican cuisine, making it a great choice for a pre-theater meal.
restaurants.name: Toloache

restaurants.bio: If you’re coming from a show at Radio City, particularly around the holidays, there’s a good chance you’re with an out-of-towner (i.e. your dad) that “wants a good steak.” As long as your dad doesn’t mind a slightly rowdy vibe, you should bring him to Quality Meats.
restaurants.name: Quality Meats

restaurants.bio: If your dad doesn’t want steak, he probably wants Italian. The Quality people have dad-friendly (and really just everyone-friendly) food and big, visually impressive environments down pat.
restaurants.name: Quality Italian

restaurants.bio: As much as we like a good performance, we’re often most excited about a trip to Midtown because it means we have a good reason to go to Danji.
restaurants.name: Danji

restaurants.bio: This place feels like a cross between a country club and the Playboy mansion, which makes it perfect for a big time pre or post Radio City meal.
restaurants.name: The Lambs Club

restaurants.bio: The National might not be the best restaurant in Midtown, but it might be the most reliable. This brasserie’s eats are always solid, and while they’re not cheap, they’re also not horrifyingly pricey.
restaurants.name: The National

restaurants.bio: The best seats at this iconic Soho bistro are at the bar, where you'll inevitably wind up sandwiched between a neighborhood regular with stories about Basquiat, and a martini-drunk stranger who's dying to tell you about the Miami crypto scene.
restaurants.name: Raoul's

restaurants.bio: From outside, Emilio's Ballato seems generally insufferable. Seven days a week, the Nolita celebrity hotspot ushers A-listers into its not-so-secret back room and feeds them spaghetti.
restaurants.name: Emilio’s Ballato

restaurants.bio: You don’t come to Wu’s to show off for strangers. You come to hang out with your friends, which makes this Cantonese spot the most wholesome scene of all.
restaurants.name: Wu's Wonton King

restaurants.bio: It’s impossible to define the scene at this Greenwich Village trattoria. There’s too much going on.
restaurants.name: Bar Pitti

restaurants.bio: Around in some form since 1847, this Italian-ish tavern is a legendary spot where Bob Dylan used to hang out.
restaurants.name: Fanelli Cafe

restaurants.bio: You can technically eat a pretty good burger here on a regular Tuesday, but that's not how you should do Jean's.
restaurants.name: Jean's
restaurants.address: 415 Lafayette St New York, New York 10003

restaurants.bio: The steak au poivre at Lucien has a powerful, tingly bite. But if anyone tells you that they come here for the food, they’re lying.
restaurants.name: Lucien

restaurants.bio: Casino is very Dimes Square, but it’s not Kiki’s Dimes Square. Things are more upscale around here.
restaurants.name: Casino

restaurants.bio: This spot in the bottom of the Mercer Hotel is across from Fanelli on Prince Street.
restaurants.name: Sartiano’s

restaurants.bio: Le Dive was destined to be sceney. It didn’t have a choice.
restaurants.name: Le Dive

restaurants.bio: Fouquet’s is not a democratic restaurant. It is not for the people.
restaurants.name: Brasserie Fouquet’s

restaurants.bio: You can have a nice time at this West Village restaurant, even if it's a little dull.
restaurants.name: American Bar

restaurants.bio: BondSt has its charms. (The serviceable sushi, for example.)
restaurants.name: BondSt

restaurants.bio: If you wanted to know where Catch currently lands in the culture, it most recently had a moment on RHONY.
restaurants.name: Catch

restaurants.bio: Endorsed by both Fat Joe and Rosario Dawson, Casa Adela is pretty much synonymous with NYC Puerto Rican food. The beloved neighborhood spot, founded in 1976 by the late Adela Vargas, is a great place to bring a few friends for tostones, mofongo, and chicharrón de pollo with rice and beans.
restaurants.name: Casa Adela

restaurants.bio: Weekend afternoons, Angel Jimenez holds court in a cluttered Mott Haven trailer, hacking at roast pig while posing for photos and handing out samples. With thick skin that shatters like peanut brittle, that roast pig is, without a doubt, the best lechón in the city.
restaurants.name: Lechonera La Piraña

restaurants.bio: This Bronx institution is a pork specialist, serving stewed pig ears, crackly chicharrón, and garlicky mofongo mixed with pernil since 1983.
restaurants.name: 188 Cuchifritos

restaurants.bio: Spanish Harlem is one of the Puerto Rican epicenters of New York, and La Fonda Boricua has been one of its most recognizable restaurants for the past 25 years.
restaurants.name: La Fonda Boricua

restaurants.bio: This East Harlem institution on 116th (with a second location at 188th) is another icon.
restaurants.name: Cuchifritos

restaurants.bio: Thanks to its rainbow lights and salsa music, Sofrito feels a bit like a nightclub.
restaurants.name: Sofrito

restaurants.bio: Hit up the Langston Hughes House on 127th Street, then grab lunch at this tiny counter-service spot that’s been around for over 30 years.
restaurants.name: Lechonera La Isla

restaurants.bio: Home to some of the best pasteles in the city, The Freakin Rican started as a Puerto Rican food truck.
restaurants.name: The Freakin Rican

restaurants.bio: Cuchifritos will obviously be part of your order at this Williamsburg restaurant.
restaurants.name: La Isla Cuchifritos

restaurants.bio: Kiosko 787 serves crispy empanadillas, arroz mamposteao, and big stacks of mofongo with your choice of protein from a streetside counter in Gowanus.
restaurants.name: Kiosko 787

restaurants.bio: Despite the name, this decades-old Soundview restaurant specializes in Puerto Rican staples like pastelillos, chuletas, and chicharrón de pollo.
restaurants.name: The South of France

restaurants.bio: Though technically across the Broome Street border into Nolita, Torrisi in the historic Puck Building feels emblematic of the Italian-American neighborhood. The restaurant is from the people behind Carbone, and while it shares some DNA (impressive design, servers in tuxedos, general pageantry), it’s bigger and more interesting, with inventive dishes (chopped liver with Manischewitz jelly) that are just as good as the classics (spaghetti with lamb amatriciana). If you can’t get a reservation—and you probably can’t—try the walk-in-only bar area for a special night out.
restaurants.name: Torrisi Bar & Restaurant

restaurants.bio: If you told owner Emilio Sr. his restaurant was in Little Italy—it’s just north, on Houston—he might blacklist you from the (constantly long) line forever. But red sauce is a state of mind, and for a classic New York Italian experience, there’s no better option than this vintage 1956 restaurant. Expect a wait at the celebrity-swarmed hotspot, which regularly entertains the likes of Taylor Swift and Barack Obama with big platters of buttery baked clams and off-menu veal parm smothered in vodka sauce.
restaurants.name: Emilio’s Ballato

restaurants.bio: Di Palo's is a long-standing specialty grocer on Grand Street, beloved since 1910 for their impressive selection of Italian meats, cheeses, and other pantry treasures. Right next door, the family's romantically lit wine bar, C. Di Palo, serves some of those same excellent products, as well as panini and off-the-beaten-path wines from more than 20 regions of Italy.
restaurants.name: C. Di Palo Wine Bar

restaurants.bio: Parisi Bakery opened in 1903, and once counted Frank Sinatra among its regulars. The man had taste: They make excellent crusty bread here, and even better sandwiches. From cold cuts to meatball parm, just about every Italian deli standard is available—but The Dennis is the sandwich scribbled at the very top of their chalkboard menu for good reason.
restaurants.name: Parisi Bakery

restaurants.bio: Rubirosa, also technically in Nolita, is known for its thin-crust pies and bustling dining room that’s about the width of a subway car. If you need a place for a casual birthday or an impressive group dinner—whether in Little Italy, or any part of town—this restaurant should be near the top of your list.
restaurants.name: Rubirosa

restaurants.bio: You go to Pasquale Jones in Nolita for two things: wine and pizza. This Italian restaurant also serves pasta, small plates, and a few proteins cooked in a wood-burning oven—but don’t get distracted. The pizzas are puffy and chewy, with an appropriate amount of char.
restaurants.name: Pasquale Jones

restaurants.bio: If you long for a classic Little Italy experience—an old-school Italian joint smack in the middle of the chaos of Mulberry Street—Il Cortile (in operation since 1975) is precisely where you should go.
restaurants.name: Il Cortile

restaurants.bio: Open since 2022, Pep’s On Grand is a newcomer along the geologic timescale of a neighborhood where multiple restaurants have been operating for more than a century.
restaurants.name: Pep's On Grand
restaurants.address: 197 Grand St, New York, NY 10013 New York, New York

restaurants.bio: There’s no shortage of gelato in Little Italy, but everything served at Figo Il Gelato Italiano is especially creamy and vivid.
restaurants.name: Figo Il Gelato Italiano
restaurants.address: 178 Mulberry St New York, New York 10012

restaurants.bio: This spacious, rustic Italian restaurant on the corner of Mulberry and Grand is a good option for groups and families, not to mention diners in a rush.
restaurants.name: Gelso & Grand

restaurants.bio: If you’ve walked through Little Italy even once, you’ve noticed Ferrara Bakery, with its neon signs and enormous ice cream cones mounted above the awning.
restaurants.name: Ferrara Bakery & Cafe

restaurants.bio: Da Nico hosted the Sopranos 25th anniversary party, which gives them quite a bit of Mulberry Street cred.
restaurants.name: Da Nico

restaurants.bio: A Little Italy fixture since 1891, Caffé Roma is widely acknowledged to be the oldest Italian bakery in New York.
restaurants.name: Caffé Roma

restaurants.bio: As long as you don’t have your heart set on a full-service East Village brunch experience, you should try some of the $9 toasts at Smor. This all-day cafe makes a bunch of different open-faced sandwiches with smoked fish and really good rye bread.
restaurants.name: Smor

restaurants.bio: Gertie is another all-day cafe, but in Williamsburg by the JMZ at Marcy Avenue. Eating here is what we imagine it’d be like to live in a really nicely designed makeup bag: bright pastel walls, curved ceilings, and things you want to look at and touch.
restaurants.name: Gertie

restaurants.bio: San Marzano’s inexpensive brunch isn’t a secret by any means - but that doesn’t mean it’s not worth coming here when you want $4 mimosas and $8 panini.
restaurants.name: San Marzano

restaurants.bio: Westville - which has seven locations across the city - is a reliable and relatively inexpensive choice. The food is straightforward and mostly healthy, with dishes ranging from benedicts to cobb salads.
restaurants.name: Westville Dumbo

restaurants.bio: House Of Small Wonder is near the Bedford L Stop in Williamsburg, but you feel a little more like you’re in a treehouse when you eat brunch here.
restaurants.name: House of Small Wonder

restaurants.bio: Egg Shop is very committed to the brunch brand, which isn’t a bad thing. It just means that almost everyone eating here is having a casual catch-up with friends.
restaurants.name: Egg Shop

restaurants.bio: If you’ve ever waited in line for the fluffy, buttery pancakes at Clinton Street Baking Co., you should know that you can get the same ones at Community Food & Juice in Morningside Heights.
restaurants.name: Community Food & Juice

restaurants.bio: Maybe your friends are always looking for brunch places where they can drink multiple rounds of mimosas, eat things like chilaquiles or a breakfast burger, and not pay a ton of money for all of that.
restaurants.name: Esperanto

restaurants.bio: If you’re in the Disney World part of Williamsburg and you don’t want to spend as much money as you would at the actual Disney World, Mekelburg’s Domino is your spot.
restaurants.name: Mekelburg’s

restaurants.bio: People seem to be mostly unaware of the fact that Al Di La in Park Slope is open for weekday lunch and weekend brunch.
restaurants.name: Al Di La

restaurants.bio: Le Bonbonniere is one of the last classic diners in lower Manhattan, which means you might see someone famous eating pancakes here.
restaurants.name: La Bonbonniere

restaurants.bio: Jing Fong is one of our all-time favorite group brunch spots, even when we’re not keeping a close eye on our checking accounts.
restaurants.name: Jing Fong

restaurants.bio: This is an Israeli restaurant where you can get challah French toast or hummus falafel for $11.
restaurants.name: 12 Chairs

restaurants.bio: At Balade in the East Village, all the Lebanese brunch dishes come with homemade bread, salad, and orange juice or coffee.
restaurants.name: Balade

restaurants.bio: Maybe it’s one of those Sunday afternoons when you’ve decided you’re too tired to process the week you just had, and also too tired to think about the week ahead.
restaurants.name: J.G. Melon

restaurants.bio: Located in Flushing, this place has some of the juiciest Afghan kebabs and largest portions of broth-simmered rice in the city.
restaurants.name: Kabul Kabab House

restaurants.bio: This spot specializes in halal versions of classic American dishes, like Southwest egg benedict and Nashville hot fried chicken and waffles.
restaurants.name: Farine Baking Company

restaurants.bio: A halal Xinjiang cuisine restaurant known for its cumin sauteed beef and hearty portions.
restaurants.name: Jiang Diner

restaurants.bio: A popular soul food spot in Boerum Hill, known for its oxtail and jerk chicken.
restaurants.name: The Soul Spot

restaurants.bio: A Bay Ridge restaurant serving Palestinian classics like hummus and shawarma.
restaurants.name: Ayat

restaurants.bio: A go-to for great halal Thai food, known for its pad Thai and grilled skirt steak.
restaurants.name: Top Thai Vintage

restaurants.bio: A fully halal establishment known for its cheesesteaks and crispy fries.
restaurants.name: Tony Luke's

restaurants.bio: Specializes in upscale takes on classic soul food, including Cajun-style seafood.
restaurants.name: Black Nile

restaurants.bio: A South African-Portuguese restaurant known for its peri-peri chicken.
restaurants.name: Chicky's

restaurants.bio: A Bangladeshi restaurant offering a variety of Bengali-style dishes.
restaurants.name: Boishakhi Restaurant

restaurants.bio: A family-owned Guyanese-Chinese restaurant known for its fried chicken fried rice.
restaurants.name: Carifesta Halal Restaurant
restaurants.address: 12615 Liberty Ave South Richmond Hill, NY 11419

restaurants.bio: A to-go-style Middle Eastern spot known for its quality meats and platters.
restaurants.name: Duzan

restaurants.bio: Casual Uyghur restaurant specializing in laghman noodles and kebabs.
restaurants.name: Nurlan Uyghur Restaurant

restaurants.bio: A classic Yemeni restaurant known for its lamb haneeth and homemade bread.
restaurants.name: Yemen Cafe

restaurants.bio: Located in the old Breslin space in the Ace Hotel, Koloman takes the kind of food you’d expect to find at a fancy hotel in Europe, gives it a 21st-century makeover, and then serves it all up in a surprisingly casual setting.
restaurants.name: Koloman

restaurants.bio: L’Abeille, a high-end French-Japanese restaurant in Tribeca, might just restore your faith in the tasting menu format.
restaurants.name: L'Abeille

restaurants.bio: Kru focuses on reinterpreting century-old Thai recipes, and every dish is a showstopper.
restaurants.name: Kru

restaurants.bio: Masalawala & Sons serves hyper-specific regional Indian food that you’ll describe in great detail to everyone you know for months after you eat it.
restaurants.name: Masalawala & Sons

restaurants.bio: Place des Fêtes is a casual Clinton Hill spot with dishes on par with top fine-dining spots in NYC.
restaurants.name: Place des Fêtes

restaurants.bio: Dept of Culture serves a four-course menu inspired by the food of North-Central Nigeria.
restaurants.name: Dept. Of Culture
restaurants.address: 327 Nostrand Avenue New York, New York 11216

restaurants.bio: Laser Wolf offers charcoal-grilled skewers and bottomless mezze with a spectacular view of the Manhattan skyline.
restaurants.name: Laser Wolf

restaurants.bio: 53’s location next to MoMa feels fitting, with an elaborate design and excellent food.
The Noortwyck gets us excited about eating New American food with consistently excellent dishes.
restaurants.name: The Noortwyck

restaurants.bio: Potluck Club does fun, modern takes on Cantonese American cuisine.
restaurants.name: Potluck Club

restaurants.bio: Bonnie’s brings Cantonese-American comfort food to a lively corner of Williamsburg.
restaurants.name: Bonnie’s

restaurants.bio: Nudibranch offers a menu influenced by South America, Mexico, and various Asian countries.
restaurants.name: Nudibranch

restaurants.bio: Kjun serves Cajun dishes with subtle Korean twists in a casual setting.
restaurants.name: Kjun

restaurants.bio: Little Flower Cafe is a cool place to be, serving excellent coffee and comfort food.
restaurants.name: Little Flower Cafe

restaurants.bio: Felina Cucina is a great spot to leisurely eat a sausage and peppers pizza while you wait out a weather delay. Watch your pizza rotate in the giant stone oven, sip a Negroni sbagliato, and make a drinking game out of spotting travelers zooming around the terminal on suitcase scooters.
restaurants.name: Felina Cucina

restaurants.bio: The original 1911 Smokehouse in Trenton is known for heaping platters of smoked meat, and you can also get their pulled pork sandwiches and wings in Terminal A. The crispy rib tips are great for appeasing your grumpy sibling who just started a carnivore diet, and the vegan wings and black bean empanadas will satisfy just about everyone else.
restaurants.name: Smokehouse BBQ

restaurants.bio: City Rub Cafe is small enough that you might walk by without noticing it, but it’s one of the best places to eat in the terminal. The seared ahi tuna salad and coconut shrimp are the perfect light snacks, and the crispy and moist chicken sandwich is cozy and satisfying without being too salty or rich.
restaurants.name: City Rub Cafe

restaurants.bio: Nothing is guaranteed when it comes to air travel—except people standing up as soon as the seatbelt sign turns off. But one thing you can count on is Carlitos for some excellent tacos on fresh made tortillas at the airport.
restaurants.name: Carlitos

restaurants.bio: Terminal A has a small business corridor highlighting local Jersey bakers and sweet shops, so definitely explore the area if you need a pick-me-up after getting a tub of homemade tiramisu confiscated by TSA.
restaurants.name: Bang Cookies

restaurants.bio: Stick to the pizza and stromboli at this grab-and-go counter in Terminal B. Go for the Jersey Devil with pepperoni and cherry hot peppers, or the Garden State, which is loaded up with zucchini, yellow squash, artichokes, and roasted red peppers.
restaurants.name: Little Tony's Pizzeria

restaurants.bio: These small but mighty fridges are scattered through various airports, typically filled with healthy grain bowls, salads, and wraps that cost about $10.
restaurants.name: Farmer's Fridge

restaurants.bio: Terminal C is pretty massive, so if your flight is near gates C120-140, you’ll want to park yourself nearby. Thankfully, Flora is tucked away in this part of the concourse.
restaurants.name: Flora
restaurants.address: Terminal C, near Gate C133 New York, Newark 07114

restaurants.bio: This ramen bar is located at the center of the main food court, so you can kill a few hours drinking sake, people-watching tourists decked out in sweatshirts they bought on Canal Street, and slurping noodles before your flight.
restaurants.name: Kaedama

restaurants.bio: Little Purse has two locations in Terminal C, a tiny dining room with one central velvet booth near Gate 75, and a larger space closer to Gate 103.
restaurants.name: Little Purse
restaurants.address: Newark International Airport New York, Newark 07114

restaurants.bio: This tavern near Gate 81 has a huge menu that covers just about every traveler’s needs, minus noise-canceling headphones.
restaurants.name: Vesper Tavern

restaurants.bio: Abruzzo is a surprisingly good Italian spot that has enough flatscreens for you to find something to watch from any table.
restaurants.name: Abruzzo Italian Steakhouse

restaurants.bio: A croque madame is always a good idea, and thankfully Saison serves theirs all day.
restaurants.name: Saison

restaurants.bio: Daily is one of the few airport restaurants where you might actually forget for a second you’re about to wrestle your rolling bag into an overhead compartment.
restaurants.name: Daily

restaurants.bio: Going to Dog Day Afternoon is like stopping by your neighbor’s place for a bite, if your neighbor had a Ms. Pacman machine, a sick vintage record collection, and enough wit to name a hot dog joint after a classic heist movie that was shot in the neighborhood. This standing room-only spot makes excellent Chicago-style hot dogs, sandwiches, and sausage-oriented sides. Everything is best enjoyed with an orange whip, a frozen drink that tastes like hopes, dreams, and the eternal optimism of youth.
restaurants.name: Dog Day Afternoon

restaurants.bio: Brancaccio’s calls itself a “food shop” because it sells a little bit of everything—from red sauce pasta dishes and roast chickens to homemade pastries and some of Brooklyn’s best Italian sandwiches. When you don’t feel like cooking but want something that tastes homey, the prepared foods behind a small counter are the best option in Windsor Terrace. Have a look at the handwritten menu near the cash register, and note that this is not the kind of place where you ask for substitutions.
restaurants.name: Brancaccio's Food Shop

restaurants.bio: When you’re planning to hang out with your friends for hours, this ideal neighborhood gastropub has everything you want: a rotating draft list that’s more exciting than it needs to be, a consistently excellent playlist that spans genres and decades, lots of big tables for group hangs, and a giant chalkboard in lieu of a menu for easy ordering. Their “Everything but the Wings” (basically Japanese sweet potatoes given the hot wings treatment) is a destination-worthy dish, and this is the kind of spot where you can get a pint and a salad, knowing that both will be good every time.
restaurants.name: The Double Windsor

restaurants.bio: Terrace Bagels makes the kind of fluffy, flavorful bagel that New York expats dream about after they’ve moved away. The flavors are pretty traditional and there’s nothing too cool or overly fussy about this spot, which is exactly what makes it special. Unlike many bagel shops, there’s actually seating both inside and on the sidewalk—but Terrace Bagels is also very close to the park...and bagels just taste better when you eat them on a green bench under a tree.
restaurants.name: Terrace Bagels

restaurants.bio: Syko is a grab-and-go spot that defies the accepted logic of most restaurants that serve food from two different cultures. There’s no fusion here—instead, half the menu is Korean, and the other half is Syrian. Both halves have standout items, like the Syrian sujok sandwich and the Korean vegetable kimbap. We like either for a quick breakfast or lunch on a nice day, since Syko is a four-minute walk to Prospect Park (we’ve timed it). They also have a shaded outdoor structure with tables if you forgot to bring your picnic blanket.
restaurants.name: Syko

restaurants.bio: Krupa is one of those great all-purpose restaurants that anyone would be lucky to have in their neighborhood. There’s a big, sunny backyard and sidewalk tables out front—unsurprisingly, this place gets busy on nice weekends. It’s an especially kid-friendly restaurant, so no one will side-eye you if you pull a stroller up to a big table. The menu leans Mediterranean, and items like house-made chicken nuggets and a “babycino” (Brooklynese for steamed milk with cinnamon) feel very on brand for the area.
restaurants.name: Krupa Grocery

restaurants.bio: The sweet potato falafel at this tiny Israeli cafe are excellent, but it’s the eggplant sandwiches (only available on Wednesdays) that will have you rearranging your WFH schedule. There are a few tables inside, a few tables outside, and it’s pretty much always packed with locals. Batata also serves malawach sandwiches for breakfast—one sweet, one savory—and a handful of smoothies. Stop here on your way to the park for a long morning walk, or after you’ve finished an early run.
restaurants.name: Batata Pita Bar

restaurants.bio: If you’re into locally sourced everything, you’ll love Daytime, which sources their coffee from a Red Hook-based roaster, and have a well-curated grab-and-go selection with everything from wine to half-pints of salad and jam. Even simple things like yogurt and granola somehow feel special in this airy space with big windows. Daytime almost always has a line, and it only gets longer on the weekends. To snag one of the few counter stools and camp out with your laptop on a weekday, get there when they open.
restaurants.name: Daytime

restaurants.bio: If you want to feel like you’re leaving Brooklyn entirely, get an outdoor table under a canopy of colorful tapestries in Bedawi Cafe’s backyard garden. This Jordanian spot does classics very well, so you won’t go wrong with a platter of tabbouleh, falafel, foul, and merguez, but the specialty dishes, like chicken ouzi, really shine. Bedawi is perfect for a leisurely lunch or a casual dinner, and is one of our favorite summer date night spots.
restaurants.name: Bedawi Cafe

restaurants.bio: East Wind Snack Shop is your best bet for a solid dim sum-style meal without venturing over to Sunset Park’s Chinatown. The menu, like the space, is concise but well curated. Grab a counter seat and get an order of pan-fried juicy pork buns and Incredible Har Gow, which show up to the party dressed in a lacy skirt with a drizzle of abalone sauce. East Wind is a good local lunch-break spot for days when you need to step away from your screen.
restaurants.name: East Wind Snack Shop

restaurants.bio: If Italian bakeries were an essential part of your childhood, you’ll get an instant nostalgia-induced serotonin boost from walking into Regina. There’s nowhere to sit, but the entire interior smells like cookies, so you’ll want to linger anyway. Come here for rainbow cookies, sfogliatelle, lobster tails, and every other Italian bakery staple imaginable. They also have a great selection of seasonal baked goods, from iced cookies to highly pigmented buttercream-frosted cupcakes.
restaurants.name: Regina Bakery Inc.

restaurants.bio: Take it to Shu Jiao Fu Zhou. Order the saucy peanut noodles for $3.25, and 10 steamed pork-and-chive dumplings for $5.
restaurants.name: Shu Jiao Fu Zhou Cuisine

restaurants.bio: An East Village restaurant with sister locations in Flushing and Midtown, known for its umami, garlic-heavy dishes.
restaurants.name: Szechuan Mountain House
restaurants.address: 23 Saint Marks Pl New York, NY 10003

restaurants.bio: A popular spot on the lower end of the LES, known for its huge menu and fast service.
restaurants.name: Wu's Wonton King

restaurants.bio: Serves both Shanghainese and Cantonese classics in a casual setting.
restaurants.name: Liu's Shanghai

restaurants.bio: A tiny, takeout-only window in Flushing known for its wontons with hot sauce.
restaurants.name: White Bear

restaurants.bio: Brooklyn's answer to White Bear, known for its hot and spicy wontons.
restaurants.name: Mama's Noodle House

restaurants.bio: A large, lively restaurant serving nostalgic food with a twist.
restaurants.name: Potluck Club

restaurants.bio: A modern homage to Chinatown with inventive Cantonese American food.
restaurants.name: Phoenix Palace

restaurants.bio: Known for its variety of soup dumplings.
restaurants.name: Shanghai You Garden

restaurants.bio: A hot pot restaurant designed like a rural Chinese village.
restaurants.name: Chong Qing Lao Zao

restaurants.bio: An upscale spot for tender cumin beef and refreshing pork belly.
restaurants.name: Alley 41

restaurants.bio: An expansive Cantonese restaurant with a wide variety of dim sum.
restaurants.name: Asian Jewels Seafood Restaurant

restaurants.bio: A stall in Flushing's New York Food Court known for its crab roe dishes.
restaurants.name: Xie Bao
restaurants.address: 133-35 Roosevelt Ave, Flushing, NY New York, NY 11354

restaurants.bio: A Sichuan restaurant known for its grilled fish.
restaurants.name: Chuan Tian Xia

restaurants.bio: Spotlights the seafood dominant cuisine of the region around Shanghai.
restaurants.name: CheLi
restaurants.address: 19 Saint Marks Pl New York, NY 10003

restaurants.bio: Open since 1982, known for its Shanghainese food.
restaurants.name: Deluxe Green Bo

restaurants.bio: A Sichuan restaurant known for its extensive menu.
restaurants.name: Sky Pavilion
restaurants.address: 325 W 42nd St New York, New York 10036

restaurants.bio: Specializes in the seafood-centric cuisine of Ningbo.
restaurants.name: YongChuan

restaurants.bio: A big, pastel-and-neon wonderland of Hong Kong-style food.
restaurants.name: Kong Sihk Tong

restaurants.bio: Known for its affordable, magnificent food.
restaurants.name: Wah Fung No. 1 Fast Food

restaurants.bio: Makes some of the freshest dim sum in Chinatown.
restaurants.name: Royal Seafood Restaurant

restaurants.bio: Known for its peking duck.
restaurants.name: Hwa Yuan

restaurants.bio: A new-school Fujianese restaurant in Prospect Heights.
restaurants.name: Nin Hao
restaurants.address: 609 Dean St New York, New York 11238

restaurants.bio: A Cantonese restaurant with a lively dining room.
restaurants.name: Uncle Lou

restaurants.bio: Specializes in Hong-Kong style noodle soup.
restaurants.name: Maxi’s Noodle

restaurants.bio: The menu at this Italian restaurant is loaded with hits: mafalda ribbons made one-by-one in the kitchen, fresh-pressed pizzelle that forms the cannolis you’re going to want for dessert, and a linguini nero that has its own following of regulars who come weekly for a fix of the black ink pasta with clams in a complex garlic, chile, and tomato infusion.
restaurants.name: Augustine’s Salumeria

restaurants.bio: Walter’s has been a Mamaroneck institution for over 100 years, and if you’ve never waited in line for hot dogs from a roadside pagoda, this is your chance.
restaurants.name: Walter’s Hot Dog Stand

restaurants.bio: This French spot in a rebuilt farmhouse bordering Connecticut is a good place to watch chefs stir mushrooms into risotto just so, and maybe have a Martha Stewart sighting.
restaurants.name: Cenadou

restaurants.bio: La Bastide opened in February 2024, in the same farmhouse location as the much-loved Cenadou. It occupies the lower level of the property, and offers multi-course tasting menus at luxury price points.
restaurants.name: La Bastide
restaurants.address: 721 Titicus Rd North Salem, New York 10560

restaurants.bio: Odo has immaculate dinner party vibes. The restaurant glows a little from the street, there’s a happy buzz in the small dining room, and the staff welcomes you like an old friend.
restaurants.name: Odo

restaurants.bio: We can’t think of a more 'farm-to-table' restaurant than Blue Hill at Stone Barns, where you drive past your dinner on the way to eating it.
restaurants.name: Blue Hill At Stone Barns

restaurants.bio: There’s a lot going on at Goosefeather, a Hong Kong-style Cantonese barbeque and noodle place set in a manor house on an estate in Tarrytown.
restaurants.name: Goosefeather

restaurants.bio: The best wings in Westchester are at Candlelight Inn, a roadside bar in Scarsdale.
restaurants.name: Candlelight Inn

restaurants.bio: Chinese restaurant O Mandarin is perfect for a Sunday night family dinner, a group celebration, or even just some comfort food to-go.
restaurants.name: O Mandarin

restaurants.bio: At almost 15 years old, The Cookery in Dobbs Ferry is like a punk rock band that’s gone mainstream.
restaurants.name: The Cookery

restaurants.bio: This cash-only, 24/7 deli has been around for 60 years, and rumor has it they haven’t locked the front door or turned off the lights in over 23 years.
restaurants.name: Rocky’s Millwood Deli
restaurants.address: 235 Saw Mill River Rd Millwood, NY 10546

restaurants.bio: There are a handful of highly regarded Indian restaurants in Westchester, and our favorite is Chutney Masala in Irvington.
restaurants.name: Chutney Masala

restaurants.bio: Everything about Oko in Rye says 'you’ve made it,' from the difficult-to-score prime-time reservations to the luxury items all over the Japanese menu.
restaurants.name: OKO Kitchen

restaurants.bio: You’ll notice two things when you walk into Boro6 in Hastings: the 40-foot-long marble horseshoe bar, and the everyone-knows-your-name welcome from the staff.
restaurants.name: Boro6

restaurants.bio: Like a great Disney movie, Mt Kisco Diner works on two levels.
restaurants.name: Mt Kisco Diner
restaurants.address: 252 E Main St Mount Kisco, NY 10549

restaurants.bio: Classic spots like Johnny’s and Sal’s are probably what come to mind first when you think of the pizza scene in Westchester, and they remain beloved.
restaurants.name: Burrata

restaurants.bio: Anyone who’s driven up 95 has undoubtedly noticed the evolution of high-rise developments dotting downtown New Rochelle.
restaurants.name: Town House Kitchen + Drinks
